instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ...again....
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos and the rest of you nice people :)

Well here I am again with my favorite nightmare board , the 3332 ....
This time i have a board with some oxidation and no green light at all ....
No liquid damage noticed (the sensors still white) , while checking it out on the microscope i noticed that the <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> are blown , so I thought this will be one easy one :) (optimistic ha ) 
replaced those two and connected the charger to see if all is ok now , and as you might guess it was NOT :)
The <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> tried to communicate with me the old indian way , sending me smokesignals just before it died , puffff 
The <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> didnt but that is probably because the battery wasnt connected .... 
Removed the <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and replaced it thinking that might solve the problem , it didnt . Checked the <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> for short and it seems ok , only the pin 5 goes to ground ....
On pin 1 of the <RESISTOR>R6920</RESISTOR> i do get 18.5 V so that side seems ok so my problem must be on the other side unfortunately .
On the <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> pin 3 in diode mode i get 0.213 and on pin 2 on L6995 in diode mode i get 0.315 V ....
And there I am stuck .... any help is highly apreciated 
Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ...again....
threads.message:
"replaced it thinking"
NO, you must change in base of some reason; justfied by measurments, of curse.
Thiking and praying will not solve problems; apart of sentimental ones ;).

"replaced those two and connected the charger"
When you replace components, ALWAYS check for short, or low/incorrect values, BEFORE applying power on the board.

"<DIODE>D6905</DIODE> pin 3 in diode mode i get 0.213"
Not short, nor even "too" low, but really INCORRECT; in fact much lower than normal.

Remove <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/91/93 (one by one) and check again.
If still incorrect, change <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ...again....
threads.message:
Thank you 2informaticos for your answer , if you are not here we can close the forum :)
I did apply a prayor before but as you said it did not help ?
I did heck for short but couldnt find one , the value on pin 3 of the <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> is very low , I wish a had another working board to see what the value should actually be .
I will remove the <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> /91/ 93 and see if the value changes . 
Thanks again for your answer !

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ...again....
threads.message:
Well what can I say , as usual you are the champ !!!!!
It was the <CAPACITOR>C6993</CAPACITOR> , mark this thread as SOLVED (thanks to 2 informaticos )

THANK YOU SOOOOO MUCH
Fixing a board after 2 days can feel better than sex sometimes :)

threads.message: I wouldn't know I've never fixed a board ?
